lesson.title: Visualizations and Tying it Together
lesson.summary: This lesson ties everything together. It covers effective visualizations depending on the problem you are solving, and reviewing a data presentation end to end.

atoms.title: text intro
atoms.text:
The final consideration in telling an effective data story is interpreting your analyses. So what? Why do your outputs matter to a management team? Often times, the simplest analyses can be the most powerful in having an entire organization take action. How do you effectively communicate your data story and deliver a concise set of recommendations? 

In the final data presentation example, you’ll see how the key concepts we’ve learned thus far work together. Why does defining a problem statement up front matter so much? Why does building out an issue tree with structured hypothesis help you save time and stay focused? Why does a ghost deck help you think ahead on what your analysis will look and feel like? What are effective visualizations based on varying problem statements? And how does it all look together.

atoms.title: Visualizations_table
atoms.text:
### This lesson ties everything together by: Running through types of effective visualizations depending on the problem you are solving, and Reviewing a data presentation end to end that encompasses all of the concepts we’ve learned thus far. In the final data presentation example, you’ll see how the key concepts we’ve learned thus far work together. Why does defining a problem statement up front matter so much? Why does building out an issue tree with structured hypothesis help you save time and stay focused? Why does a ghost deck help you think ahead on what your analysis will look and feel like? What are effective visualizations based on varying problem statements? And how does it all look together? ## Types of Visualizations: ### Relationships: When your problem statement requires understanding the relationship between 1+features
Example vizualizations include:__ Correlation plots, Regressions__ ### Comparison: When your problem statement requires the comparison of two data features or cohorts
Example vizualizations include:__ Box plots__ ### Temporal: When your problem statement requires understanding changes to 1+ features across time
Example vizualizations include:__ Time plots__ ### Distribution: When enabling your problem statement requires understanding the biases in your data
Example vizualizations include:__ Maps__ ### Metric Outputs: When showcasing the results to your problem statement centers on the outcomes (e.g., experimentation, prediction, performance metrics, etc.)
Example vizualizations include:__ Chart metrics__

### Definition When your problem statement requires understanding the relationship between 1+features __ Example__
*Problem statement reads:* How do the demographic characteristics of a FIFA player affect his market value? __Which test will give the appropriate visualization?__ 1. When both your variables are *numeric*, Pearson correlation or Regressions are a good choice 2. When both your variables are *categorical*, Chi-square test or any other non-parametric test can be used.
Here are some resources on non-parametric tests: * [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonparametric_statistics) * [Investopedia](https://www.investopedia.com/terms/n/nonparametric-statistics.asp) * [Blog from minitab.com](https://blog.minitab.com/blog/adventures-in-statistics-2/choosing-between-a-nonparametric-test-and-a-parametric-test) 3. When one variable is *categorical* variable and the other a *numerical variable*, ANOVA test is a good choice
Here are some resources on ANOVA tests: * [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Analysis_of_variance) * [Blog from minitab.com](https://blog.minitab.com/blog/adventures-in-statistics-2/understanding-analysis-of-variance-anova-and-the-f-test) * When you need to run an ANOVA test on multiple dependent variables, statisticians use MANOVAs, but outside academic research, these are rarely used in the industry. Nonetheless, if you are curious, here is a link to explore this topic more in-depth: * [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multivariate_analysis_of_variance) * [ResearchGate post](https://www.researchgate.net/post/What_is_the_difference_between_ANOVA_MANOVA)

### Definition When your problem statement requires the comparison of two data features or cohorts __ Example__
*Problem statement reads:* What are the demographic differences between the Top 10% of FIFA players by market value and the remaining 90% of players? __Which visualization will work best?__ 1. Box plots will provide a comprehensive picture of how the two cohorts are comparing: * Center will tell if on average the cohorts are similar * Spread will tell you if they vary differently * Shape (symmetry, skewness) will indicate any asymmetry * Unusual features (outliers, missingness) If you need a refresher on box plots, feel free to explore the refresher course on descriptive statistics available in our pre-requisite courses within the classroom.
__Citation for the image used in the slide: __ https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Langliffe_Population_Time_Series_Graph_(1881-2011).jpg

### Definition When your problem statement requires understanding changes to 1+ features across time __ Example__
*Problem statement reads:* How have the number of small brands (<$10m in revenue) changed in the past 10 years compared to larger, CPG strategics (P&G, Unilever, etc.)? __Which visualization will work best?__
Time plots will allow you to show how the cohorts changed across time and how they are different. Time plots are also known as time-series plots. The following links to creating time series plots are just some resources on the web. * [Minitab example of multiple variables](https://support.minitab.com/en-us/minitab-express/1/help-and-how-to/graphs/time-series-plot/create-the-graph/multiple-y-variables-simple/) * [Stack Overflow question for creating time series plots in Excel](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/14344482/excel-plot-time-series-frequency-with-continuous-xaxis)

### Definition When enabling your problem statement requires understanding the biases in your data __ Example__
*Problem statement reads:* Why has crime in NYC neighborhoods decreased by 10% in the past 5 years? __ Which visualization works best?__
* Distribution visualizations: * __Maps__: Also known as Bubble maps, these visual tools can be effective in creating visual cues for users on how the distribution spread is: Bigger bubble, larger distribution. * If you use R, here is [documentation on how to create these bubble maps](https://www.r-graph-gallery.com/bubble-map/) * __Density plot:__ These are very similar to a histogram and use numerical values as the dependent variable.
* If you use R, here is the [documentation for how to create density plots](https://www.r-graph-gallery.com/density-plot/) * A [Statexchange post about interpreting heights of density plots](https://stats.stackexchange.com/questions/147885/how-to-interpret-height-of-density-plot)

#### Definition When showcasing the results to your problem statement centers on the outcomes (e.g., experimentation, prediction performance metrics, etc.) __Example__
*Problem statement reads:* How do we effectively predict the stock price of Apple 2 months from now? __What visuals work best here?__
* Metric Outputs: * __Performance metrics__ (predictions, ANOVA tests, Chi Square test). In these types of stories, you need to share out the actual metrics from your various statistical tests, whether it is regression prediction, ANOVA F tests results, Chi-square analysis. * Here again is the [Minitab resource on ANOVA](https://blog.minitab.com/blog/adventures-in-statistics-2/understanding-analysis-of-variance-anova-and-the-f-test) that shows the F-test outputs and how to interpret it. * And here is the [blog from minitab.com](https://blog.minitab.com/blog/adventures-in-statistics-2/choosing-between-a-nonparametric-test-and-a-parametric-test) about Chi-square tests

complex_prompt.text: Match the Statement to the Type of Visualization

concepts.text: How has the availability of organic products changed over the last year?
How does the region of wine relate to the quality of wine?
How do your Top 20% of customers differ from the remaining 80%?
How has the stock price of Amazon changed over the last year?

atoms.title: Exercise 1
atoms.text:
** Instructions**

You are the manager of a team of data scientists. Your client is FIFA, and a few weeks into the job, your team is asked to pull together a set of visualizations to help focus the client on the progress made thus far.

The problem statement, for your reference, has already been defined:

What drives the current market value for the Top 10% of FIFA players?

Your task is to build out a set of visualizations that help progress the problem statement. Use a set of hypotheses you think are relevant.

Dataset link: [https://www.kaggle.com/karangadiya/fifa19](https://www.kaggle.com/karangadiya/fifa19)

## Pre-processing done on FIFA dataset

Here is a link to the Google spreadsheet with the [solution dataset](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1QdG3At_CYczyE6U1koVkOmiJOFFRqbUIMc-fNB_AuPU/edit?usp=sharing)

### Create Player Ranking by Value
To create a ranking for the players by value, there were several pre-processing steps that needed to be completed.
1. The numerical value needed to be extracted or parsed out from the `Value` column. This required some Excel parsing using INDEX and ROW functions in columns titled `character` and `digit`.
2. Next the value needed to be normalized to ensure that `value`s in thousands (K) and millions (M) were standardized. See how the Excel IF function was used to in combination with the `character` column to get the normalized value.
3. From there on, the player was ranked based on the new normalized value data in the `normalized` column.

### Create Normalized Height
1. Similarly, the get the normalized height, various Excel functions were used to obtain a normalized height column titled `normalized2`.

### Create Normalized Length of Time since Joining
1. To create the length of time since the player had joined, the `Joined` column was used to create a `joined normalized` column by using Excel's TODAY function.

#### Additional Note
To create outlier thresholds, you can use the following formulae: `IQR*1.5 + Q3 value`

## Solution to Exercise 1:

We have provided the solution for Exercise 1 over the next several concepts. We do a walk through for every part of the visualization. 

Again, as mentioned on the previous page: we have also provided the processed data file that is used for this solution. Here it is again at the bottom of the page for your convenience.

You can also find a copy of the dataset in Google spreadsheets if you wish to: Click [here](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1QdG3At_CYczyE6U1koVkOmiJOFFRqbUIMc-fNB_AuPU/edit?usp=sharing)
